clinical_study.brief_title: Feasibility of Lactate Level Evaluation in Prehospital Care in Trauma
clinical_study.official_title: Feasibility of Lactate Level Evaluation in Prehospital Care in Trauma

brief_summary.textblock: Capillary or venous lactate level evaluation in prehospital care could be simple and beneficial tool for optimising prehospital care in patients with severe trauma.

detailed_description.textblock: Evaluation of blood lactate level and its trend are important morbidity and mortality predictive factors. In prehospital care, lactate level is more sensitive marker and have better prognostic value in severe trauma than basic vital signs. Worse outcome is associated with levels between 2 - 4 mmol/l. Measurement of lactate level in venous or capillary blood is quick and simple method with minimal risks and with no special needs for medical staff training. In spite of good availability of this method in the Czech Republic the method feasibility has never been analysed in patients with severe trauma.

primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 day - the time the patient is treated by Emergency Medical System
primary_outcome.description: Proportion of subjects with measured and recorded prehospital lactate level

arm_group.description: All patients having / suspected to have severe trauma injuries

intervention.intervention_name: capillary and venous lactate level measurement
intervention.description: capillary and venous lactate level measurement

study_pop.textblock: Patient having / suspected to have severe trauma

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patient having / suspected to have severe trauma treated by cooperating Emergency Medical System organization
Exclusion Criteria:
- possible alterations of plasma lactate level in the time of trauma (seizure, malignity, use of beta-2 agonists, severe liver and/or kidney failure, ketoacidosis, intoxication)
